{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Betrayed | image = Betrayed_poster.jpeg | image_size = 215px | alt = | border = no | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Costa-Gavras]] | producer = [[Irwin Winkler]] | writer = [[Joe Eszterhas]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Debra Winger]] * [[Tom Berenger]] * [[John Heard (actor)|John Heard]] * [[John Mahoney]] }} | music = [[Bill Conti]] | cinematography = Patrick Blossier | editing = Joële Van Effenterre | production companies = {{Plainlist| * CST Telecommunications Co. * [[Irwin Winkler|Winkler Films]] * [[United Artists]] }} | distributor = [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|MGM/UA Communications Company]] | released = {{Film date|1988|08|26}} | runtime = 127 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: --><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/betrayed-1970-1 | title=''Betrayed'' (18) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=November 10, 1988 | accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $19 million | gross = $25.8 million<ref name=mojo/> }} '''''Betrayed''''' is a 1988 American [[Drama (film and television)|drama]] [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] film directed by [[Costa-Gavras]], written by [[Joe Eszterhas]], and starring [[Debra Winger]] and [[Tom Berenger]]. The plot is roughly based upon the terrorist activities of American [[neo-Nazi]] and [[White supremacy|white supremacist]] [[Robert Jay Mathews|Robert Mathews]] and his group [[The Order (white supremacist group)|The Order]].
==Plot== Set in the American Midwest, the film begins with the murder of a Jewish radio host in [[Chicago]]. [[FBI]] [[undercover]] agent Catherine Weaver, alias Katie Phillips, sets out to [[wiktionary:Infiltrate|infiltrate]] a farming community, suspected of harboring those responsible.
After receiving a warm welcome from land-owner and farmer Gary Simmons, his two children and [[extended family]], she begins to believe that the FBI lead is erroneous. Throwing caution to the wind, she falls in love with Simmons, a [[Vietnam War]] veteran who appears to command the respect of the local community. A short while later, her suspicions are aroused by talk of family secrets and as more chilling events unfold, Katie is exposed to the fact that Gary is the leader of a [[Ku Klux Klan|Klan-like]] [[white supremacy]] group involved in heinous, often gut-wrenching, acts of racial violence.
In too deep, Katie pleads with boss and mentor Michael Carnes to release her from the assignment, but he refuses, instead turning the screw on her mixed loyalties. Ultimately, she must betray either the man she loves or the country she has sworn to protect.
==Cast== * [[Debra Winger]] as Catherine "Cathy" Weaver / Katie Philips * [[Tom Berenger]] as Gary Simmons * [[John Heard (actor)|John Heard]] as Michael "Mike" Carnes * [[Betsy Blair]] as Gladys Simmons * [[John Mahoney]] as Shorty * [[Ted Levine]] as Wes * [[Jeffrey DeMunn]] as Bobby Flynn * [[Albert Hall (actor)|Albert Hall]] as Al Sanders * [[David Clennon]] as Jack Carpenter * [[Richard Libertini]] as Sam Kraus * [[Timothy Hutton]] (''cameo'') as a juggler at the fair * [[Ralph Foody]] as Lyle
==Reception==
===Critical response=== ''Betrayed'' was met with mixed reviews, with [[Rotten Tomatoes]] giving it a 42% "Rotten" rating based on 12 reviews.<ref>[http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1002205-betrayed/ RottenTomatoes.com rating information]</ref> Winger's performance was praised by some reviewers, who felt she was successful in conveying complex and mixed emotions throughout. Critics of the film point to a muddled and sometimes unbelievable unravelling of the plot.
The opening sequence is loosely based on the 1984 murder of Denver DJ [[Alan Berg]], which was carried out by white supremacists known as [[The Order (white supremacist group)|The Order]].
In a 1996 interview, Berenger named ''Betrayed'' as his favorite film, shrugging off any media criticism with the retort "It was exactly what it was meant to be".<ref>[http://www.tv.com/tom-berenger/person/29375/biography.html Tom Berenger Biography at www.tv.com] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080928121632/http://www.tv.com/tom-berenger/person/29375/biography.html |date=September 28, 2008 }}</ref>
===Box office=== The film debuted at #2 at the box office,<ref>{{cite news|title= WEEKEND BOX OFFICE : National Box Office Goes Soft|work= [[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1988-08-30/entertainment/ca-1481_1_box-office|accessdate=2011-03-21}}</ref> earning $5,534,787 and coming in behind the second weekend of ''[[A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=1988&wknd=35&p=.htm | title=Weekend Box Office Results for August 26-28, 1988 | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Amazon.com]] | date=August 29, 1988 | accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref> The film would go on to gross $25,816,139 in the United States.<ref name=mojo>{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=betrayed.htm | title=''Betrayed'' (1988) | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Amazon.com]] | accessdate=November 18, 2016}}</ref>
==See also== * ''[[Talk Radio (film)]]'' * ''[[American History X]]'' * ''[[Green Room (film)|Green Room]]'' * ''[[Imperium (2016 film)|Imperium]]'' * [[Terrorism in the United States#White supremacy|White supremacist terrorism in the United States]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{IMDb title|0094731|Betrayed}} * {{Mojo title|betrayed|Betrayed}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|1002205-betrayed|Betrayed}}
{{Costa-Gavras}} {{Joe Eszterhas}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Architectural Practice |image = City Market, Indianapolis.jpg |caption = [[Indianapolis City Market]] |name = Bohlen, Meyer, Gibson and Associates (BMG) |architects = |city = [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] |coordinates= |founded = 1853 (as D. A. Bohlen, Architect) |dissolved = |awards = |significant_buildings= |significant_projects = |significant_design = }}
'''Bohlen, Meyer, Gibson and Associates''', or '''BMG''', is an architectural firm based in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]]. It was founded in Indianapolis on April 10, 1853, as '''D. A. Bohlen, Architect''' by [[Diedrich A. Bohlen]], German immigrant. In 1884, after Diedrich's son, Oscar D. Bohlen, joined the firm it was renamed '''D. A. Bohlen and Son'''. Four successive generations of Bohlen architects have worked at the firm: Diedrich A. Bohlen (its founder), Oscar D. Bohlen (Diedrich's son), August C. Bohlen (Diedrich's grandson), and Robert L. Bohlen (Diedrich's great-grandson). The firm specialized in institutional projects, especially civic, religious, and educational buildings. In 1971 Melvin B. G. Meyer acquired majority interest in the firm, which adopted its name in reference to its founder and its two principal architects, Meyer and John M. Gibson. The architectural firm is among the oldest still operating in the United States. More than twenty of its projects are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].
==History== [[Diedrich A. Bohlen]], a native of [[Cadenberge]], [[Kingdom of Hanover]], immigrated to the [[United States]] around 1851, and founded D. A. Bohlen, Architect, on April 10, 1853 at [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]].<ref name=HBR>{{cite web | title =Historic Business Register: Bohlen Meyer Gibson and Associates | work = | publisher =Indiana Historical Society | date = | url =http://www.indianahistory.org/our-services/books-publications/hbr/bohlen-meyer-gibson.pdf | format =PDF | accessdate =2015-09-01}}</ref> Bohlen is credited for introducing the German [[Neo-Gothic architecture|Neo-Gothic]] style to Indiana.<ref name=Smith>Richard Smith, "Bohlen, Meyer, Gibson and Associates", in {{cite book | editors=David J. Bodenhamer and Robert G. Barrows | authorlink = | coauthors = | title =The Encyclopedia of Indianapolis | work= | volume = | series = | edition = | page =334 | publisher = Indiana University| location = Bloomington and Indianapolis | year =1994 | isbn =0-253-31222-1}}</ref> The designs for several of his buildings, including the [[Indianapolis City Market]] façade (1886), exhibit the [[Romanesque Revival architecture]] style called [[Rundbogenstil]].<ref name=ICMkt>{{cite web| title =City Market| work =Discover Our Shared Heritage Travel Itinerary: Indianapolis | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service| date = | url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/indianapolis/citymarket.htm | accessdate =2015-09-15}}</ref>
More than twenty of the Bohlen firm's projects are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]], including [[Morris-Butler House]] (1864), Indianapolis;<ref name=MBHouse>{{cite web| author=Wesley I. Shank| title =National Register of Historic Places Inventory–Nomination Form: Morris-Butler House | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service| date =August 1971| url =http://focus.nps.gov/GetAsset?assetID=8641da90-d602-44d1-80cc-3e81496cfe63| format =PDF| accessdate =2015-09-02}}</ref> Foley Hall (1860, 1897), [[Saint Mary-of-the-Woods College]];<ref name=Foley>{{cite web | author=Sister Ann Kathleen Brawley | title =National Registration of Historic Places Inventory–Nomination Form: Foley Hall | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service | date =1981-01-05| url = http://focus.nps.gov/GetAsset?assetID=a1a7ac39-1e76-4dfe-b613-ec3cf33d7c77| format =PDF | accessdate =2015-09-03}}</ref> [[St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church (Indianapolis, Indiana)|Saint John the Evangelist Catholic Church]] (1871), rectory (1863) and bishop's residence (1878), Indianapolis;<ref name=Widner>{{cite web|author1=Rev. Thomas Widner |author2=Sister Marie Wolf |lastauthoramp=yes | title =National Register of Historic Places Inventory––Nomination Form: St. John's Church and Rectory | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, Heritage Conservation and Recreation Service | date =1980-07-11 | url = https://secure.in.gov/apps/dnr/shaard/r/2c8bf/N/St._John's_Church_&_Rectory_Marion_CO_Nom.pdf | format =pdf | accessdate =2015-09-02}}</ref> Roberts Park Methodist Church (1876), Indianapolis;<ref name=Cord>{{cite web| author=Ruby J. Cord | title =National Register of Historic Places Inventory–Nomination Form: Roberts Park Methodist Episcopal Church | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service| date =1979-08-13| url =http://focus.nps.gov/GetAsset?assetID=6397cbf5-043b-4535-b1b3-fb9d67a6b90c| format =PDF| accessdate =2015-09-02}}</ref> [[Crown Hill Cemetery]]'s [[Crown Hill Cemetery#Structures|Gothic Chapel]] (1877);<ref name=CHChapel>{{cite web| author=Wesley I. Shank| title =National Register of Historic Places Inventory–Nomination Form: Crown Hill Cemetery (Portion) | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service| date =August 1971| url =http://focus.nps.gov/GetAsset?assetID=bbd7ec28-76b9-48a9-b757-62abaecb1569| format =PDF| accessdate =2015-09-02}}</ref> Indianapolis City Market (1886);<ref>{{cite web|author1=H. Roll McLaughlin |author2=David R. Hermansen |lastauthoramp=yes | title =National Register of Historic Places Inventory–Nomination Form: Indianapolis City Market | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service| date =1974-02-04| url =http://focus.nps.gov/GetAsset?assetID=c0de878a-a0c3-423b-8a16-e81d0356588d| format =PDF| accessdate =2015-09-02}}</ref> Indianapolis's [[Majestic Building (Indianapolis, Indiana)|Majestic Building]] (1896);<ref name=Majestic>{{cite web|author1=Samuel A. Roberson |author2=Sheryl D. Roberson |lastauthoramp=yes | title =National Register of Historic Places Inventory ––Nomination Form: Majestic Building | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service| date =1980-03-18| url = http://focus.nps.gov/GetAsset?assetID=9441152f-98d5-4dcd-9f92-664bdb172bfe | format =PDF| accessdate =2015-09-24}}</ref> and the [[Indianapolis Fire Headquarters and Municipal Garage|Indianapolis Fire Department headquarters (1913) and municipal garage (1913)]],<ref name=FireHQ>{{cite web| author=Margaret Warminski| title =National Register of Historic Places Registration Form: Indianapolis Fire Headquarters and Municipal Garage | work = | publisher =U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service| date =2002-01-18| url =http://focus.nps.gov/GetAsset?assetID=9441152f-98d5-4dcd-9f92-664bdb172bfe| format =PDF| accessdate =2015-09-24}}</ref> among others.<ref name=Smith/>
Bohlen's firm is among the oldest architectural firms still operating in the United States. Four successive generation of Bohlen architects have worked at the Indianapolis firm. Diedrich Augustus Bohlen founded the firm in 1853. Oscar Diedrich Bohlen, D. A.'s son, joined the firm around 1882, and became a partner in 1884. August Carl Bohlen, Oscar's son, joined the firm in 1910, and later co-authored [[Indiana]]'s original building codes. Robert Lesh Bohlen, August's son, joined the firm in 1946.<ref name=Walton42-44-45>{{cite journal | author=Lloyd B. Walton | title =Past Masters of Mortar | journal =Indianapolis Star Magazine | volume = | issue = | pages =42, 44–45 | publisher = | location =Indianapolis, IN | date =1978-06-11 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=Jacob Piatt Dunn Jr. | title =Indiana and Indianans: A History of Aboriginal and Territorial Indiana and the Century of Statehood| work= | volume =IV | series = | edition = | page =1845| publisher =American Historical Society| location =Chicago| year = 1919 | OCLC =2470354}}</ref>
D. A. Bohlen, Architect, went through several name and ownership changes after Bohlen's descendants, new partners, and associates joined the firm. In 1876 Matthew Roth became D. A. Bohlen's business partner, and for a few years the firm was named Bohlen and Roth. In 1884, after Bohlen's son, Oscar, joined the firm, its name was changed to D. A. Bohlen and Son, Architects. Following D. A. Bohlen's death on June 1, 1890, Oscar continued the family firm on his own until 1910, except for the period between 1897 and 1899, when Hugo Zigrosser was his partner.<ref name=HBR/><ref>{{cite book |author1=Douglas A. Wissing |author2=Marianne Tobias |author3=Rebecca W. Dolan |author4=Anne Ryder |last-author-amp=yes | title =Crown Hill: History, Spirit, and Sanctuary | publisher =Indiana Historical Society Press | edition = | year =2013 | location =Indianapolis | pages =124 | url = | isbn =9780871953018}}</ref> After Oscar's death in 1936, his son, August, who joined the firm in 1910, and August's son, Robert, continued the family's presence at the architectural firm until the mid-twentieth century. Following Robert's death in 1960, August Bohlen entered into a partnership with David V. Burns.<ref name=HBR/><ref name=Probst10>{{cite book |author1=George T. Probst |author2=Eberhard Reichmann |lastauthoramp=yes | title =The Germans in Indianapolis, 1840–1918 | work= | volume = | series = | edition = | page=10| publisher =Indiana University-Purdue University at Indianapolis, German-American Center, and the Indiana German Heritage Society| location =Indianapolis, IN| year =1989| OCLC=20996951}}</ref>
The firm was renamed Bohlen and Burns Architects in 1961, and incorporated as Bohlen, Burns and Associates in 1967. With August's retirement in 1970, ownership passed from the Bohlen family to Melvin B.G. Meyer and John M. Gibson, the firm's main architects, and Noel Cord, the firm's accountant. Meyer, who joined firm in 1946 as a draftsman, served as its main designer from 1948 to 1990. In 1971 Meyer acquired majority interest in the firm, which adopted the name, Bohlen, Meyer, Gibson and Associates, Inc. in reference to its founder, D. A. Bohlen, and its two principal architects, Meyer and Gibson. Mike Rogers and Hans Megerling, also architects in the firm, replaced Cord as investors in the firm in 1980. Following Meyer's retirement from the firm in 1990, Mr. and Mrs. John V. Schneider of the Schneider Corporation purchased the architectural firm. Although the firm's original location in Indianapolis is not known, its offices were housed in several downtown locations, before moving to more suburban locations, including the Meadows Office Complex (1970–78), Castleton, (1978–91), and North Post Road, (1991– ).<ref name=HBR/><ref name=Meyer>{{cite news | title =Architect Melvin B. G. Meyer, 75, Designed Numerous Local Buildings | newspaper =Indianapolis Star | location =Indianapolis, IN | page =E10 | language = | publisher = | date =1995-12-20 | url = | accessdate = }}</ref>
==Major clients and projects== The firm specialized in institutional structures for religious, educational, and civic institutions, although it did design some private residences for well-do-to families, such as the French mansard-style Morris-Butler House (1864) in Indianapolis and the [[Jacobethan|Neo-Jacobean]]-style Churchman House (1871) on a farm that later became part of [[Beech Grove, Indiana]].<ref name=MBHouse/><ref>{{cite book | author=Wilbur Peat | title =Indiana Houses of the Nineteenth Century | work= | volume = | series = | edition = | pages=131 and 156 and plates 155 and 181 | publisher = Indiana Historical Society| location = Indianapolis | year = 1962 | OCLC=191192}}</ref><ref name=Churchman>"Biographical Sketches" in {{cite web | title =Francis M. Churchman Family Collection, 1866–1928, 1966 Collection Guide | work = | publisher =Indiana Historical Society | date =February 2012 | url = http://www.indianahistory.org/our-collections/collection-guides/churchman-family-collection.pdf/ | format =PDF | accessdate =2015-09-02}}</ref> The firm did not enter the multi-family housing market until 1993.<ref name=HBR/>
Most of the Bohlen firm’s early projects were in the Indianapolis area. Notable exceptions include the [[French Lick Springs Hotel]] (1898), designed by Oscar Bohlen, in [[French Lick, Indiana]], and numerous buildings for the [[Sisters of Providence of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods]] at [[Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana]].<ref name=Probst106>Probst and Reichmann, p. 106.</ref> The firm's architects also designed Oldenburg Convent (1899), Oldenburg Academy (1898), and other buildings for the [[Third Order of Saint Francis#Sisters of St. Francis (Oldenburg, Indiana)|Sisters of Saint Francis]] at [[Oldenburg, Indiana]], as well as buildings at The Carmel of Saint Joseph, a [[Carmelites|Carmelite]] monastery in [[Allendale, Indiana]].<ref name=Meyer/><ref>{{cite book | title =Historical Sketch of the Convent and Academy of the Sisters of St. Francis in Oldenburg, Indiana: and the Work of Their Community in the United States | publisher =Sisters of Saint Francis Community | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1901 | location =Oldenburg, IN | pages = | url = | OCLC=10864015}}</ref>
In 1891 Bohlen's firm submitted a design for a proposed Indiana building to be erected at the [[World's Columbian Exposition]] (1893) at [[Chicago]]. The selection committee narrowed its choice to two plans, one from the Bohlen firm and the other from [[Wing & Mahurin|Wing and Mahurin]] of [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]]. In a controversial move from the committee's leadership, a design proposed by Chicago architect [[Henry Ives Cobb]] was recommended to the Indiana Board of World's Fair Managers and built for the exposition, despite protests from the Indiana architects who argued that Cobb's plan arrived after the contest deadline.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Frank A. Cassell |author2=Marguerite E. Cassell |lastauthoramp=yes | title =Pride, Profits, and Politics: Indiana and the Columbian Exposition of 1893 | journal =Indiana Magazine of History | volume =80 | issue =2 | pages =99–100 | publisher =Indiana University | location =Bloomington, IN | date =June 1984 | language = | url =http://scholarworks.iu.edu/journals/index.php/imh/article/view/10540/14791| accessdate =2015-09-24}}</ref> Although the Bohlen firm did not receive this prestigious commission, it designed other projects built outside of Indiana at [[Cleveland|Cleveland, Ohio]]; [[Dayton, Ohio]]; [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]]; [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]]; and [[St. Louis|Saint Louis, Missouri]].<ref name=HBR/>
===Sisters of Providence projects=== One of the firm's earliest and long-standing clients was the [[Sisters of Providence of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods]]. D. A. Bohlen established a relationship with the Sisters of Providence in the 1850s that continued over several decades. Boheln's firm completed "more than sixty projects" for the Sisters.<ref name=HBR/>
Providence motherhouse and chapel (1853–4, 1863), Foley Hall (1860), and the [[Church of the Immaculate Conception (Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana)|Church of the Immaculate Conception]] (1892) are among Diedrich Bohlen's early renovations and designs for the Sisters of Providence on the grounds of [[Saint Mary-of-the-Woods College]], a [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] [[liberal arts college]] near [[Terre Haute, Indiana]].<ref name=Foley/><ref name=Logan56>{{cite book | author=Eugenia Logan | title =The History of the Sisters of Providence of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods | publisher =Benziger Brothers | series =History of the Sisters of Providence of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana | volume =II | edition = | year=1949 | location =New York | page =56 | url = | OCLC=5523512}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| author =Mary Roger Madden | title =The Path Marked Out | publisher =Sisters of Providence | series = History of the Sisters of Providence of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana; Sisters of Providence History Series| volume =III | edition = | year =1991 | location =Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, IN | pages=128–29 | url = | OCLC= 27393597}}</ref> A fire destroyed the motherhouse in 1889, and Foley Hall has been demolished, but the Church of the Immaculate Conception is still in use.<ref>Logan, pp. 326–28, and {{cite book | title =A Journey of Love, Mercy, and Justice: A Pictorial History of the Sisters of Providence of Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Celebrating 150 Years of Service Among the People of God | publisher=The Sisters of Providence | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1989 | location =Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, IN | page=15 | url = | isbn=}}</ref> Construction on the Church of the Immaculate Conception began in 1886. After D. A. Bohlen's death in 1890, Oscar continued his father's legacy as community architect at Saint Mary-of-the-Woods. The church's interior decoration was completed in 1907, and it underwent a major renovation in 1987, with Melvin Meyer as the project architect.<ref>Madden, p. 183; ''A Journey of Love, Mercy, and Justice'', p. 24; and {{cite book | title =The Church of the Immaculate Conception | publisher =Sisters of Providence | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1987 | location =Saint Mary–of-the-Woods, IN | pages = | url = | isbn =}}</ref>
The Bohlen firm designed several additional buildings for Sisters of Providence, including an addition to Foley Hall (1897), a new novitiate (1904), Guerin Hall (1913), Saint Cecilia Conservatory of Music (1913), Le Fer Hall (1924), and [[Blessed Sacrament Chapel (Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana)|Blessed Sacrament Chapel]] (1924).<ref name=Foley/><ref>Madden, pp. 135–37, 382–84, 396, and 519–20.</ref> Robert Bohlen, the last of D. A. Bohlen's descendants to design a building for the Sisters of Providence, designed Owens Hall (1960).<ref>Madden, p. 573.</ref> The firm's president, Melvin B. G. Meyer, designed a new library and chapel in the Providence motherhouse and Providence Center.<ref name=Meyer/>
===Indianapolis projects=== Many of the firm's most notable religious, civic, commercial, and residential buildings were erected in Indianapolis. These include buildings designed by the firm's founder, D. A. Bohlen, his descendants, and Melvin B. G. Meyer.
Bohlen's early commissions in the city included the Charles Mayer store façade (1853), the dome for Odd Fellows Grand Lodge (1854), and the Metropolitan (1858), the city's first theater.<ref name=Smith/><ref>Costigan designed the Odd Fellows Grand Lodge, but D. A. Bohlen completed it after Costigan's death. See {{cite book | author=Berry R. Sulgrove | title =History of Indianapolis and Marion County, Indiana | publisher =L. H. Everts and Company | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1884 | location =Philadelphia | page =373 | url = | OCLC=3558051}}</ref> Indianapolis's German community was another source of early commissions for the firm. D. A. Bohlen was the architect for the city's German-English Independent School (1860) on Maryland Street and the General German Protestant Orphans' Home (1872), later known as Pleasant Run Children's Home, on South State Avenue.<ref name=Probst36-37>Probst and Reichmann, pp. 36–37.</ref><ref name=Walton44>Walton, p. 44.</ref>
The firm designed several of Indianapolis's notable churches and cemetery structures. D. A. Bohlen designed the United Evangelical Zion Church (1866) on West Ohio Street; his firm also designed its replacement, Zion United Church of Christ (1913), at North and New Jersey Streets.<ref>Probst and Reichmann, p. 10, and {{cite book| title =The History of Nine Urban Churches| publisher =The Riley-Lockerbie Ministerial Association of Downtown Indianapolis | location =Indianapolis, IN | url =| isbn=}}</ref> D. A. Bohlen designed [[Crown Hill Cemetery]]'s [[Crown Hill Cemetery#Structures|Gothic Chapel]] (1875), and his firm designed an addition to the structure in 1917.<ref name=CHChapel/> Crown Hill's Community Mausoleum, designed by the Bohlen firm, was completed in the early 1950s. In 1960 the firm drew up plans for the cemetery's first garden crypts.<ref name=Crown>Wissing, Tobias, Dolan, and Ryder, pp. 17, 42, 47, 124, 182, 188, and 286.</ref><ref name=Sanford10>{{cite book | author=Wayne L. Sanford | title =Crown Hill, 1863–1988: 125th Anniversary Edition | publisher = Crown Hill Cemetery Association | year =1988 | location =Indianapolis, IN | pages = | url = | isbn =}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title =Crown Hill Cemetery, Chapel and Vault, Thirty-fourth Street, Indianapolis, Marion County, IN | work =Historic American Buildings Survey | publisher =Library of Congress | url =https://www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/hh/item/in0048/ | format = | accessdate =2014-06-20}}</ref>
D. A. Bohlen also designed [[St. John the Evangelist Catholic Church (Indianapolis, Indiana)|Saint John the Evangelist Catholic Church]] (1871), the main structure in a cluster of parish buildings on the southwest corner of Georgia Street and Capitol Avenue in Indianapolis that includes a D. A. Bohlen-designed rectory (1863) and bishop's residence (1878). D. A. Bohlen's son, Oscar, designed the twin spires on the two towers that flank the church's main [[façade]] and supervised their construction in 1893.<ref name=Widner/><ref name=Divita21-23>{{cite book | author =James J. Divita | title =Indianapolis Cathedral: A Construction History of Our Three Mother Churches | publisher =Catholic Archdiocese of Indianapolis | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1986 | location =Indianapolis, IN | pages =21–23 | url = | isbn =}}</ref><ref name=ArtArch>{{cite book | title =The Art and Architecture of Nine Urban Churches | publisher =The Riley-Lockerbie Ministerial Association of Downtown Indianapolis | series = | volume = | edition = | year = | location = Indianapolis, IN | pages = | url = | isbn =}}</ref> Other D. A. Bohlen-designed buildings for the parish include Saint Johns School for Boys (1867), across the alley from the rectory, and the Saint Johns Academy for Girls (1874), on nearby Maryland Street. Both of these buildings were later demolished.<ref name=Divita21-23/>
Other notable churches designed by D. A. Bohlen include the [[Romanesque Revival architecture|Romanesque Revival]]-style Roberts Park Methodist Church (1876) at Delaware and Vermont Streets; Emmanuel Church (1883), later renamed Lockerbie Square United Methodist Church, at East and New York Streets; and Saint Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church (1883) at McCarty and New Jersey Streets.<ref name=Cord/><ref name=ArtArch/><ref name=StPauls>{{cite book | title =St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church: Eightieth Anniversary | publisher =Hollenbeck Press | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1922 | location =Indianapolis, IN | pages =12–13 | url = | isbn =}}</ref> Oscar Bohlen designed Assumption Catholic Church (1894). Built in West Indianapolis, a city suburb at that time, it is the oldest frame Catholic church in the city in continuous use. Also known as Saint Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church, it was later named Saint Athanasius the Great Byzantine-Ruthenian Catholic Church.<ref>{{cite book| author=Sister Francis Assisi Kennedy | title=The Archdiocese of Indianapolis, 1834–2009: Like a Mustard Seed Growing |year=2009 |publisher=Editions du Signe |location=Strasbourg, France| page=167| isbn=978-2-7468-1911-5}}</ref> Oscar also designed the parish's original school building (1895).<ref>Divita, pp. 5, 23, and 32.</ref>
Numerous commercial and several notable civic structures were designed in Indianapolis during Oscar Bohlen's tenure at the firm. D. A. and Oscar Bohlen collaborated on the [[Indianapolis City Market]] (1886),<ref name=ICMkt/> still in operation, and Tomlinson Hall (1886), adjacent to the City Market at the corner of Delaware and Market Streets. Tomlinson Hall was destroyed by fire in 1958. Oscar Bohlen's most notable commercial structure was the Majestic Building (1896), a commission from the Indiana Gas Company, at 47 South Pennsylvania Street. The ten-story, steel-skeleton building became the city's first skyscraper.<ref>{{cite book | editor=Mary Ellen Gadski | title =Indianapolis Architecture: Transformations Since 1975 | publisher =Indiana Architectural Foundation | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1993 | location =Indianapolis | page =64 | url = | isbn =9780963630018}}</ref> Oscar also designed the Indiana National Bank building (1897), a [[Neoclassical architecture|Neoclassical]] structure at Three Virginia Avenue. Demolished in 1971, it was among the first fireproof building in Indiana. Oscar's son, August, designed a six-floor addition to the bank's adjacent building.<ref name=Walton44/><ref>{{cite book|author1=Linda Weintraut |author2=Jane R. Nolan |lastauthoramp=yes | title =Pioneers in Banking: A History of the Indiana National Bank | publisher = | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1994 | location = | pages =48, 82, and 114–15 | url = | isbn =}}</ref>
August Bohlen designed the Stokely Brothers office building (1912) and the Indianapolis Star-News building (1924); however, August and Robert Bohlen's most notable design was the [[Art Deco]]-style Empire Life and Accident Insurance Company building (1950). It later became known as the [[Lilly Endowment]] building. The firm's other major projects in Indianapolis during the early twentieth century included the Oscar Bohlen-designed [[Murat Shrine|Murat Temple]] (1910) at Massachusetts Avenue and New Jersey and Michigan Streets. He also designed an addition to [[Indianapolis Union Station]] (1903) and the Pennway (1909) and Big Four (1929) buildings.<ref name=HBR/>
The Bohlen firm designed several buildings for Indianapolis's [[St. Vincent Indianapolis Hospital|Saint Vincent Hospital]], [[Methodist Hospital of Indianapolis|Methodist Hospital]], and [[St. Francis Hospital & Health Centers|Saint Francis Hospital]], among others. In 1882 D. A. Bohlen remodeled a vacant seminary building on East Vermont Street for the [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul]] to house Saint Vincent's Infirmary, predecessor to Indianapolis's Saint Vincent Hospital. Oscar Bohlen designed the hospital's second building (1889) on South and Delaware Streets, and after it was destroyed by fire in 1904, the Bohlen firm designed the third Saint Vincent Hospital (1913) building facing Fall Creek Parkway, between Capitol and Illinois Streets.<ref name=Loftus>{{cite book | author=Marie D’Andrea Loftus | title =St. Vincent Hospital and Health Care Center, Indianapolis, Indiana, 1881–1981 | publisher =Litho Press | series = | volume = | edition = | year =1981 | location =Indianapolis, IN | pages =4, 18, and 37 | url = | isbn =}}</ref><ref>Probst and Reichmann, p. 37 and 106.</ref> Oscar also designed Methodist Hospital (1901) and Saint Francis Hospital (1903).<ref name=Smith/><ref name=Vaughan>{{cite journal | author= Charles Vaughan | title = Bohlen & Son Going Strong in 4th Generation | journal =Indianapolis News | volume = | issue = | page =30 | publisher = | location =Indianapolis, IN | date = April 18, 1960 | language = | url =| accessdate = }}</ref>
During the 1970s and 1980s the firm's Indianapolis clients included Indianapolis Newspapers, Inc.; Saint Vincent Hospital; Methodist Hospital; and the Indiana National Bank, in addition to the [[Indianapolis Fire Department]], the Beveridge Paper Company, the [[University of Indianapolis]] (formerly Indiana Central University), and the Diamond Chain Company, among others.<ref name=HBR/> Melvin Meyer designed the executive offices for Indianapolis Newspapers, Inc.; the Krannert Pavilion and the Children's Pavilion at Methodist Hospital; the Krannert Library at the University of Indianapolis; and the [[Kiwanis]] International headquarters at Indianapolis.<ref name=Meyer/>
==Notable structures==
===D. A. Bohlen, Architect=== * Charles Mayer and Company store façade (1853), Indianapolis<ref name=Walton44/> * Odd Fellows Grand Lodge dome addition (1854), Indianapolis<ref name=Walton44/> * Metropolitan (1858), Indianapolis<ref name=Walton44/> * German-English Independent School (1860), Indianapolis<ref name=Probst36-37/> * Foley Hall (1860), Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana<ref name=Foley/><ref>''A Journey of Love, Mercy, and Justice'', p. 15.</ref> * Providence motherhouse and chapel (1853–4, 1863), Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana<ref name=Logan56/> * [[Morris-Butler House]] (1864), Indianapolis<ref name=MBHouse/> * Zion United Church of Christ (1866), Indianapolis<ref>{{cite book | title =Zion Evangelical United Church of Christ | publisher = | year =1995 | location = | pages =5 and 7 | url = | OCLC=36075848}}</ref> * Saint John the Evangelist Catholic Church (1871), rectory (1863), and bishop's residence (1878), Indianapolis<ref name=Widner/> * Churchman House (1871), Beech Grove, Indiana<ref name=Churchman/> * General German Protestant Orphans Home (1872), later known as Pleasant Run Children's Home, Indianapolis<ref>Probst and Reichmann, p. 112.</ref> * Roberts Park Methodist Church (1876), Indianapolis<ref name=Cord/> * [[Crown Hill Cemetery]]'s [[Crown Hill Cemetery#Structures|Gothic Chapel]] (1877), Indianapolis<ref name=CHChapel/> * Saint Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church (1883), Indianapolis<ref name=StPauls/> * Emmanuel Church (1883), renamed Lockerbie Square United Methodist Church, Indianapolis<ref>''The History of Nine Urban Churches''.</ref>
[[Image:SP-Church of the Immaculate Conception.jpg|thumb|alt=Church of the Immaculate Conception|[[Church of the Immaculate Conception (Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana)|Church of the Immaculate Conception]] ]]
===D. A. Bohlen and Son=== * [[Indianapolis City Market]] (1886)<ref name=ICMkt/> * Tomlinson Hall (1886), Indianapolis<ref name=Walton44/> * [[St. Vincent Indianapolis Hospital|Saint Vincent Hospital]] (1889, 1913), Indianapolis<ref name=Loftus/> * Providence motherhouse (1890), Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana<ref>Madden, p. 183, and ''A Journey of Love, Mercy, and Justice'', p. 24.</ref> * Indiana Dental College (1893), Indianapolis<ref name=Smith/> * [[Majestic Building (Indianapolis, Indiana)|Majestic Building]] (1896), Indianapolis<ref name=Majestic/> * Indiana National Bank building (1895)<ref name=Walton44/> * [[French Lick Springs Hotel]] (1898), French Lick, Indiana<ref name=Probst106/> * English Opera House/Theater and English Hotel (1898), Indianapolis<ref name=Vaughan/><ref>"Historical Sketch" in {{cite web | title =English Theater Records, 1902–1944 Collection Guide | work = | publisher =Indiana Historical Society | date =1986-06-10 | url = http://www.indianahistory.org/our-collections/collection-guides/english-theater-records-1902-1944.pdf/ | format =PDF | accessdate =2015-09-24}}</ref> * [[Methodist Hospital of Indianapolis]] (1901)<ref name=Smith/> * Saint Francis Hospital (1903), Indianapolis<ref name=Vaughan/> * [[Indianapolis Union Station]] addition (1903)<ref name=Smith/> * [[Church of the Immaculate Conception (Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana)|Church of the Immaculate Conception]] (1907), Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana<ref>Madden, pp. 128–29, and ''The Church of the Immaculate Conception''.</ref> * [[Murat Shrine|Murat Temple]] (1910), Indianapolis<ref name=HBR/> * Stokely Brothers office building (1912), Indianapolis<ref name=Smith/> * [[Indianapolis Fire Headquarters and Municipal Garage|Indianapolis Fire Department headquarters (1913) and municipal garage (1913)]]<ref name=FireHQ/> * Indianapolis Star-News Building (1924)<ref name=Smith/> * [[Blessed Sacrament Chapel (Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana)|Blessed Sacrament Chapel]] (1924), Saint Mary-of-the-Woods, Indiana<ref>Madden, p. 520.</ref> * [[Marygrove College]] buildings (1925–27), including Madame Cadillac Hall and the Liberal Arts building, [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]<ref>{{cite web| title =Historic Campus Architecture Project: D.A. Bohlen & Son | work = | publisher =Council of Independent Colleges | date =November 2006 | url =http://hcap.artstor.org/cgi-bin/library?a=d&d=d423 | format = | accessdate =2015-09-24}}</ref> * Empire Life and Accident Insurance Company building (1950), later known as the [[Lilly Endowment]] headquarters, Indianapolis<ref name=HBR/>

revision.text:
{{about|the line of novelty devices|the town in Kenya|Bunaba}} '''BunaB''' was the name of a line of purposely useless [[novelty item|novelty products]], promoted as if they were useful via carefully written [[marketing]] hype. They were created by American radio host [[Al Crowder]] (1904-1981). Beginning in the 1950s BunaBs were purportedly produced by the firm of Orville K. Snav and Associates and distributed from its headquarters in Snav Towers, [[Mason City, Iowa]]. The company's chief product was the Improved No. 7 BunaB, an assembly of two {{convert|1.75|in|cm|adj=on}} insulated wires, red and blue, held together with neatly applied yellow electrical tape at the ends. BunaBs have over time been viewed as examples of primitive [[conceptual art]].{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=John Charles|title=The True-Life Adventures of Captain Wa Wah|year=2009|publisher=Katydid|url=http://www.captainwawah.com/?p=bunab|accessdate=26 October 2012|chapter=25 - The Wizard of Lime Creek}} ==History== In 1951 Al Crowder was a music store employee and radio host at KSMN in Mason City.{{cite news|last=Collison|first=Jim|title=Behind the BunaB: Product Research|publisher=Globe-Gazette|date=October 6, 1962}} A cryptic gift of an object resembling a water jug from Crowder's father-in-law to Crowder's son inspired Crowder to write to the manufacturer, the [[Playtex|International Latex Corporation]], to ask what the object was. The response, received from E.C. Jakoswiak, Assistant to the President, stated that the bladder was a component of a World War II inflatable attack boat. Inspired by the apparently useless object and by the response, Crowder created the Improved BunaB #7, the first of the line. The BunaB
"...will meet, or exceed specifications set up by the industry for accuracy, durability and simplicity of operation. No moving parts insures constant stability... With a minimum of practice, results equaling the conventional instrument may be expected."
The instructions continued:
"After prolonged use the BunaB may indicate a variation of one or two percent when checked against a new BunaB. In that case, the old one should be discarded immediately. Satisfaction in positive results will readily offset the slight cost of replacement."
Those who ordered the BunaB #7 received, in addition to their device, a registration card that, when returned to Snav Towers, automatically made the recipient an "Assistant to the President." Shortly afterwards a personal letter from Crowder would arrive, discussing in lengthy detail the difficulties that attended Snav's business empire and personal life. Crowder's use of the Snav name dated to a time in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]], when he would send a daily (but empty) envelope to a local radio station that was soliciting letters from listeners. Crowder was "Chief Assistant to the President" from 1951 to his death in 1981. After he died, his wife Louise carried on as "Dame Minerva P. Snav" and managed the correspondence with the approximately 50,000 Assistants to the President and Key Personnel in the Field from the Hall of Science (an upstairs bedroom, said to cover "approximately 9000 square inches") at Snav Towers (the Crowder residence). ==BunaB product line== Snav produced a number of other BunaB products. * '''BunaB #2''', also known as '''Zudirk'''. A board game with unplayable rules. In fact, the rules clearly stated that they were unplayable. * '''BunaB #3''', the "Man's Between Shave Lotion," an apparently empty plastic bottle, the contents to be reconstituted by the addition of water. * '''BunaB #4''', a small dial with an adhesive pad that, when attached to a surface, could be moved between "OFF" and "ON." * '''BunaB #5''', a record to be played while watching television. It was entirely blank. Side 1 was noted to be particularly suitable for "drama, mystery, adventure and afternoon serials" while Side 2 was best for "panel shows, interviews, news, weather and sports." The record could be played at all [[Gramophone record|standard speeds]], including [[LP record|33-1/3]], 45, 78 and the [[Edison Disc Record|Edison 80 rpm]] standards with satisfactory results.{{cite journal|last=Asbell|first=Bernard|title=The Little World of Orville K. Snav|journal=Playboy|date=April 1958}} * '''BunaB #6''', remarkably similar to the Improved #7 BunaB to the extent of being identical. * '''BunaB #7''', the company's signature product. About 40,000 BunaB #7s were produced.{{cite book|last=Dickson|first=Paul|title=Family Words: The Dictionary for People Who Don't Know a Frone from a Brinkle|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RRLWjLs3lCgC&lpg=PA24&ots=gUebjT5y-C&dq=bunab%20crowder&pg=PA25#v=onepage&q=bunab%20crowder&f=false|publisher=Addison-Wesley|isbn=978-0934333375|pages=24-26}} The BunaB #7 is noted for its durability, ease of use and resistance to obsolescence. While not a part of the BunaB line, Snav also produced the Post Meridian Morning (PMM) Shield. This black half-disc could be attached to the left side of a clock dial to obscure the morning hours. Snav also marketed the "Exigency Conversion Apparatus" (ECA), a plastic bag containing labels "MEN" and "WOMEN," allowing instant conversion of any room to a restroom. The C-K Key, made of Snav-Metal, opened all models of [[chastity belt]]. Delinquent accounts were referred to a Snav subsidiary, the Octopus Collection Agency. ==Media coverage== Crowder appeared four times on ''[[The Garry Moore Show]]'' to discuss the BunaB #7, introducing the BunaB #5 on the show in the fall of 1957. In April 1958 Crowder was the subject of a ''[[Playboy]]'' profile entitled ''"The Little World of Orville K. Snav."'' In the ''[[Bullwinkle J. Moose|Bullwinkle]]'' cartoon series, Bullwinkle read poetry from a music stand holding the "BunaB Anthem", first aired in September 1961. [[Jay Ward]], the producer of ''Bullwinkle'', awarded Snav a "Certificate of Exceptional Adequacy".{{cite news|last=Collison|first=Jim|title=Politics, Pests stall Snav Crusade|newspaper=Globe-Gazette|date=October 6, 1962}} " ==Notable BunaB owners== Television host [[Dave Garroway]] gave away BunaB #7s to test recipients' sense of humor. The BunaB he gave to [[Jimmy Carter]] was returned. [[H.R. Haldeman]] bought one for [[Richard Nixon]].Dickson, p. 27 There is no record of whether Nixon found it funny. All of the [[Mercury Seven|Mercury 7]] astronauts had BunaBs. Other "Assistants to the President" included [[Groucho Marx]], [[Hugh Downs]], [[Jerry Lewis]], [[Helen Hayes]], [[Barry Goldwater]] (who termed it "Absolutely irreplaceable. Use it constantly"), [[Cary Grant]], [[Myrna Loy]] ("Absolutely indespensible!") and [[Hugh Hefner]]. ==As conceptual art== The BunaB line of products has been cited as an early form of [[conceptual art]], as described in the 2001 ''Dictionary of the Avant-Gardes''. BunaBs #3 and #5 are in particular cited as examples of ''praecisio'',{{cite book|author=Huth, Geof|title=A Dictionary of the Avant-Gardes|year=2001|isbn=978-0415937641|pages=25-27|edition=2nd|authorlink=Al Crowder|editor=Kostelanetz, Ric|accessdate=26 October 2012|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NZX85xdr6boC&lpg=PA144&ots=VeVdaeBKf8&dq=snav%20bunab&pg=PA144#v=onepage&q=snav%20bunab&f=false}} defined as the act of making a point through silence.{{cite book|last=Kibbins|first=Gary|title=Grammar and Not-Grammar|publisher=YYZ Artists|page=187|year=2005}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.samueljohnson.com/bunab/index.html The Improved #7 BunaB, from Orville K. Snav & Associates] with a picture of a #7 BunaB and its instruction sheet [[Category:Conceptual art]] [[Category:Novelty items]]

revision.comment: another name for Mom per Who's Who entry (and birth certificate data)
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=December 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} '''Caryl Churchill''' (born 3 September 1938, [[London]]) is a British playwright known for dramatising the abuses of power, for her use of non-[[Naturalism (theatre)|naturalistic]] techniques, and for her exploration of sexual politics and [[feminist]] themes.[http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/117251/Caryl-Churchill Caryl Churchill profile], ''Encyclopædia Britannica''; accessed 26 January 2018. ==Work== {{unsourced|section|date=January 2018}} Her early work developed [[Bertolt Brecht]]'s [[Modernism|modernist]] dramatic and theatrical techniques of [[Epic theatre]] to explore issues of [[gender]] and [[Human sexuality|sexuality]]. From ''[[A Mouthful of Birds]]'' (1986) onwards, she began to [[Experimental theatre|experiment]] with forms of [[Dance Theatre|dance-theatre]], incorporating techniques developed from the [[Performance art|performance]] tradition initiated by [[Antonin Artaud]] with his '[[Theatre of Cruelty]]'. This move away from a clear ''[[Fabel]]'' dramaturgy towards increasingly fragmented and [[Surrealism|surrealistic]] narratives characterises her work as [[Postmodern theater|postmodernist]]. ==Background== Churchill was born in London, England, the daughter of Jan Brown, a fashion model, and Robert Churchill, a political cartoonist.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/35/Caryl-Churchill.html|title=Caryl Churchill Biography (1938-)|website=Filmreference.com|accessdate=27 January 2018}} After [[World War II]], her family emigrated to [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada; Churchill was ten years old. In Montreal, she attended [[Trafalgar School for Girls]]. She returned to England to attend university, and in 1960 she graduated from [[Lady Margaret Hall]], a women's college at [[Oxford University]], with a B.A. degree in [[English Literature]].{{cite web | url=http://www.lmh.ox.ac.uk/Alumni/Prominent-alumni.aspx | title=LMH, Oxford – Prominent Alumni|website=Lmh.ox.ac.uk|accessdate=20 May 2015}} She also began her writing career there. Her four earliest plays, ''Downstairs'' (produced 1958),''You've No Need to be Frightened'', ''Having a Wonderful Time'' (1960), and ''Easy Death'' (produced 1962) were performed at Oxford by student theatre ensembles.{{cite web|url=http://www.doollee.com/PlaywrightsC/churchill-caryl.html|title=The playwrights database of modern plays|website=Doollee.com|accessdate=27 January 2018}} ==Marriage and family== In 1961 she married David Harter, a barrister.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/05/theater/newsandfeatures/the-mysteries-of-caryl-churchill.html|title=The Mysteries of Caryl Churchill|last=[[Sarah Lyall]]|date=December 5, 2004|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=22 January 2017}} They have three sons and live in [[Islington]], North London. ==Career== It was while raising a family in the 1960s and '70s that Churchill began to write short radio dramas for [[BBC]] radio. These included ''The Ants'' (1962), ''Not, Not, Not, Not Enough Oxygen'' (1971), and ''Schreber's Nervous Illness'' (1972). She also wrote television plays for the BBC, including ''The After Dinner Joke'' (1978) and ''Crimes'' (1982). These, as well as some of her [[radio plays]], have been adapted for the stage. ===Themes and plays=== {{moresources|section|date=January 2018}} In 1972, she wrote ''[[Owners (Play)|Owners]]'', a two-act, 14-scene play about obsession with power. It was her first stage play and "her first major theatrical endeavour"; it was produced in London the same year. Churchill's socialist views are expressed in the play, a critique of the values that most capitalists take for granted: being aggressive, getting ahead, doing well.{{says who|date=May 2017}} She served as resident dramatist at the [[Royal Court Theatre]] from 1974 to 1975, and later began collaboration with theatre companies such as [[Joint Stock Theatre Company]] and [[Monstrous Regiment Theatre Company|Monstrous Regiment]] (a feminist theatre collective). Both used an extended workshop period in their development of new plays. Churchill continues to use an [[improvisation]]al workshop period in developing a number of her plays. During this period, she also wrote ''Objections to Sex and Violence'' (1974). Her first play to receive wide notice was ''[[Cloud Nine (play)|Cloud Nine]]'' (1979), "a farce about sexual politics", set partly in a British overseas colony during the [[Victorian era]]. It explores the effects of the [[colonialist]]/[[imperialist]] mindset on intimate personal relationships, and uses cross-gender casting for comic and instructive effect. The play became successful in Britain and in the United States, winning an [[Obie Award]] in 1982 for best play of the year in New York. Churchill gradually abandoned more conventions of [[Realism (theatre)|realism]], and her loyalty to feminist themes and ideas became a guiding principle in her work. She won an [[Obie Award]] for best play with ''[[Top Girls]]'' (1982), "which deals with women's losing their humanity in order to attain power in a male-dominated environment." It features an all-female cast, and focuses on Marlene, who has relinquished a home and family to achieve success in the world of business. Half the action takes place at a celebratory dinner where Marlene mixes with historical, iconic and fictional women who have achieved great stature in a "man's world", but always at great cost. The other half of the play, set a year in the past, focuses on Marlene's family, where the true cost of her "successful" life becomes poignantly and frighteningly apparent. ''Softcops'' (first produced by the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] in 1984), is a "surreal play set in 19th-century France about government attempts to depoliticize illegal acts." ''[[Serious Money]]'' (1987), "a comedy about excesses in the financial world", is a verse play, chiefly written in rhyming couplets. It takes a [[satire|satirical]] look at the vagaries of the [[stock market]] and its Thatcherite denizens. The play was highly acclaimed, perhaps in part because it played immediately after the [[stock market crash]] of 1987. ''[[Icecream]]'' ([[Royal Court Theatre]] 1989) explores Anglo-American stereotypes. In ''[[The Skriker]]'' (1994), Churchill's play, a visionary exploration of global ecology made through gender games, storytelling, distorted language and evocations of modern urban life, follows an ancient and shape-shifting death portent (''The Skriker'') in her search for love, revenge and human understanding.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} "The prolific Churchill continued to push boundaries into the late 1990s. In 1997 she collaborated with the composer Orlando Gough to create 'Hotel,' a choreographed opera or sung ballet set in a hotel room. Also that year her surrealistic short play 'This Is a Chair' was produced." Her 2002 play, ''[[A Number]]'', addresses the subject of [[human cloning]] and questions of identity. Her adapted screenplay of ''[[A Number]]'' was shown on BBC TV in September 2008. Her recent play, ''Drunk Enough To Say I Love You'' (2006), takes a critical look at what she sees as Britain's submission to the United States in foreign policy. In 2010, Churchill was commissioned to write the [[libretto]] for a new short opera by [[Orlando Gough]], as part of the [[Royal Opera House]]'s ROH2 OperaShots initiative. The resulting work, ''A ring a lamp a thing'', played for five performances in the Linbury Studio Theatre at the Royal Opera House.O'Mahony, John. [https://www.theguardian.com/music/2010/jun/10/ingerland-operashots-gough-pook-sawhney "Operas about wags? Why not, says the Royal Opera House"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 10 June 2010. Her ''[[Love and Information]]'', opened at the Royal Court Theatre in September 2012, directed by [[James Macdonald (director)|James Macdonald]]. It gained great critical and popular acclaim.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}} The play, featuring 100 characters and performed by a cast of 15, is structured as a series of more than 50 fragmented scenes, some no longer than 25 seconds, all of which are apparently unrelated but which accumulate into a startling mosaic, a portrayal of modern consciousness and the need for human intimacy, love and connection. The play will have its regional premiere at Sheffield Theatres in June 2018, directed by Caroline Steinbeis. ===Translations=== Churchill has published a translation of [[Seneca the Younger|Seneca's]] ''[[Thyestes]]'' and her version of [[August Strindberg]]'s ''[[A Dream Play]]''. The latter was premiered at the National Theatre in 2005.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ===Retrospective=== The [[Royal Court Theatre]] held a 70th Birthday retrospective of her work by presenting readings of many of her most famous plays directed by notable playwrights, including [[Martin Crimp]] and [[Mark Ravenhill]].[http://www.royalcourttheatre.com/whatson01.asp?play=528] {{dead link|date=January 2018}}
Of course it's possible to trace recurring themes in Churchill's work – alienation between parent and child, the possibility and failure of revolution. But it is the variety of her work that is most striking. As Von Mayenburg says: "With each play, she discovers new genres and forms. She then discards them and moves on, opening up possibilities for other playwrights to explore. I think many people writing today don't even realise they've been influenced by her. She's changed the language of theatre. And very few playwrights do that."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2008/sep/03/carylchurchill.theatre|title='She made us raise our game'|author=[[Mark Ravenhill]]|date=3 September 2008|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK}}
===Interest in Palestine=== {{Main article|Seven Jewish Children}} Churchill is a patron of the [[Palestine Solidarity Campaign]].{{cite web|url=http://www.palestinecampaign.org/Index5b.asp?m_id=1&l1_id=2&l2_id=12|title=Patrons|work=Palestine Solidarity Campaign|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302091920/http://www.palestinecampaign.org/Index5b.asp?m_id=1&l1_id=2&l2_id=12|archivedate=2 March 2009}} In January 2009, she wrote a ten-minute play that explores a history of Israel, ending with the [[2008–2009 Israel–Gaza conflict|2008 Israeli attack on Gaza]]. It was performed for free at the [[Royal Court Theatre]], with a collection taken to donate to [[Medical Aid for Palestinians]]. ''[[The Sunday Times]]'' condemned its "ludicrous and utterly predictable lack of even-handedness"; but for ''[[The Times]]'', "there are no heroes or villains, for all that Churchill decries what is happening in Gaza". Writers such as Jeffrey Goldberg of ''[[The Atlantic]]'' and Melanie Phillips in her ''[[The Spectator|Spectator]]'' blog criticised the play as anti-Semitic,{{cite web|url=http://jeffreygoldberg.theatlantic.com/archives/2009/03/ari_roth.php#more|title=Caryl Churchill: Gaza's Shakespeare, or Fetid Jew-Baiter?|first=Jeffrey|last=Goldberg|website=Jeffreygoldberg.theatlantic.com|accessdate=27 January 2018}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/melaniephillips/3334851/the-royal-courts-mystery-play.thtml# |title=Archived copy |access-date=15 May 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090414230800/http://www.spectator.co.uk/melaniephillips/3334851/the-royal-courts-mystery-play.thtml# |archive-date=14 April 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} as did John Nathan. He noted that Churchill has said that ''[[Seven Jewish Children]]'' is "not just a theatre event but a political event."{{cite news|title=Review: Seven Jewish Children|publisher=''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]''|first= John|last=Nathan|date=12 February 2009 |url=http://www.thejc.com/articles/review-seven-jewish-children}} He suggested that a play representing views of one community and critical of that community needed to be written by a member of that community. The Royal Court denied the accusation.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2009/feb/18/caryl-churchill-gaza-play|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|title=Churchill's Gaza play accused of antisemitism|first=Charlotte|last=Higgins|date=18 February 2009|accessdate=28 April 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/letters/letters-jacobson-on-gaza-1628191.html|work=The Independent|location=London|title=Letters: Jacobson on Gaza|date=21 February 2009|accessdate=28 April 2010}} Churchill published the play, ''[[Seven Jewish Children]] – a play about Gaza'', online, for free download and use. Churchill said: "Anyone can perform it without acquiring the rights, as long as they do a collection for people in Gaza at the end of it".[https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/jan/24/theatre-gaza-caryl-churchill-royal-court-seven-jewish-children Royal Court acts fast with Gaza crisis play], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 24 January 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/video/2009/apr/25/seven-jewish-children-caryl-churchill|title=Video: Seven Jewish Children|first1=Caryl|last1=Churchill|first2=Jennie|last2=Stoller|first3=Elliot|last3=Smith|date=24 April 2009|accessdate=27 January 2018|website=Theguardian.com}} ==Prizes and awards== Churchill has received the following awards:[http://www.contemporarywriters.com/authors/?p=auth259] {{dead link|date=January 2018}} *1958 ''[[Sunday Times]]''/[[National Union of Students (United Kingdom)|National Union of Students]] Drama Festival Award Downstairs *1961 [[Richard Hillary]] Memorial Prize *1981 [[Obie Award]] for Playwriting, ''Cloud Nine'' *1982 Obie Award for Playwriting, ''Top Girls'' *1983 [[Susan Smith Blackburn Prize]] (runner-up), ''Top Girls'' *1984 Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, ''Fen'' *1987 Evening Standard Award for Best Comedy of the Year, ''Serious Money'' *1987 Obie Award for Best New Play, ''Serious Money'' *1987 Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, ''Serious Money'' *1988 [[Laurence Olivier]]/[[BBC]] Award for Best New Play, ''Serious Money'' *2001 Obie Sustained Achievement
